exchanges.user:
So been a weird few days. Work's been... I don't know, it's like everything I do isn't quite right, you know? My manager gave me feedback on this project and instead of just taking it, I spent like three hours analyzing every single thing he said, trying to figure out if he was being constructive or if he just thinks I'm incompetent. Which is stupid because I know the difference intellectually, but I just couldn't let it go.

And then I realized I've been doing this thing where I rewrite emails like five times before sending them. Five times. Just obsessing over word choice and tone like the person on the other end is going to psychoanalyze every sentence. It's exhausting and I know it's ridiculous but I can't seem to stop.

The perfectionism thing is getting worse I think. Or maybe I'm just noticing it more now. Hard to tell. Anyway, been sleeping worse too, which doesn't help with the spiral thing. But I don't want to go down the rabbit hole of analyzing why I'm not sleeping because that's just more perfectionism right? It's like I'm stuck in this loop where even recognizing the problem feels like part of the problem.

What do you think is actually going on here?
exchanges.assistant:
The pattern you're describing—manager feedback → hours of analysis, emails rewritten five times, noticing the loop while still being in it—makes a lot of sense. You're not stuck in this by accident. Your mind is trying to protect you from something. The question isn't whether you should stop analyzing (you can't just will that away), but what the analyzing is actually protecting you from. What does your mind think will happen if you send that email on draft two instead of draft five? Or if you take feedback at face value without the three-hour deep dive?

**The rewriting thing:** Five drafts isn't about finding the perfect words—it's about trying to control how someone perceives you. Your mind might be saying "if I get the tone exactly right, I can prevent them from thinking badly of me." But here's the thing: you can't actually control what they think. The perfectionism gives you the illusion of control, but it's costing you three hours of mental energy per email. What would it feel like to send draft two and let them think whatever they're going to think?

**Sleep and the meta-loop:** You're right that analyzing why you're not sleeping can become another layer of the same pattern. But there's a difference between "why am I not sleeping" (which can spiral) and "what's my body trying to tell me" (which is just listening). Sleep disruption usually means your nervous system is on high alert. The perfectionism, the email rewrites, the feedback analysis—those all keep your threat system activated. Your body doesn't distinguish between "real danger" and "what if my manager thinks I'm incompetent." It just knows: threat detected, stay vigilant.

One thing worth trying: next time you catch yourself on draft three of an email, pause. Notice the urge to keep editing. What feeling is driving it? Anxiety that they'll judge you? Fear of looking careless? Just name it, then send draft three anyway. You don't have to believe it'll be fine—just send it as an experiment and see what actually happens versus what your mind predicted. Track it: prediction vs. reality. That might give you some data on whether the five-draft insurance policy is actually buying you anything.

What feeling comes up when you imagine sending an email after two drafts instead of five?

That's not failure. That's your mind showing you what it's actually protecting against. It's not about the emails. It never was.

**The real fear:** You said it yourself—you can't control whether people think you're competent. And that uncertainty is unbearable for your threat system right now. So it grabs onto anything it can measure: draft count, word choice, response time, the exact phrasing of "sounds good." Those feel controllable, even though they're not actually giving you what you need. What you're really asking when you refresh your inbox or rewrite draft five is: "Am I safe here? Do I belong? Am I enough?" Those questions don't have email-shaped answers.

**Your manager:** You noticed he's been distant since the feedback. That might be real, might be your lens, might be both. But here's what matters: if he *is* being distant, no amount of perfect emails will fix it. And if he's *not*, your hypervigilance is exhausting you for no reason. Either way, the strategy of "control every micro-signal" isn't working. What would it look like to just ask him directly? "Hey, I noticed things have felt a bit different since that feedback conversation. Is there something we should talk about?" That's terrifying, I know. Because it gives up the illusion of control. But it also ends the guessing game.

**The exhaustion:** This isn't surprising. Your nervous system has been on high alert for weeks—scanning for threats in "sounds good" and manager body language and email tone. That's not sustainable. Your body is telling you: this vigilance has a cost. One thing that might help when you catch yourself in the loop (refreshing inbox, analyzing "sounds good"): pause and ask, "Is this actually giving me information, or is it just keeping me busy?" If it's the second one, can you redirect that energy? Go for a walk, do literally anything else for 10 minutes, then come back. Not because walking solves the problem, but because it interrupts the loop and gives your nervous system a break.

You said you're tired of managing this in your head. What if you stopped trying to manage it and just let it be messy for a bit? Not analyzing the sleep issue, not perfecting the emails, not figuring out your manager's inner state. Just: this is hard, I'm doing my best, and I can't control what other people think. What does that bring up for you?

But here's the thing: you've been working so hard to hide the "mess" that you never stopped to ask whether it's actually a problem. What if the mess is just... being human? What if the flaw you're trying to cover up is the same flaw everyone has, and the exhausting part isn't the flaw itself but the constant performance of not having one?

Then send it and see what actually happens. You've done this before with your colleague. This is the same experiment, just higher stakes. Worth trying?

You asked if this is normal or if you're spiraling. It's both. You're in the middle of something hard—realizing that a strategy you've relied on for years doesn't actually work. That's destabilizing, and yeah, it can feel like spiraling. But it's also the only way forward. You can't unlearn what you felt yesterday. Now the question is: what do you do with that clarity?

Do something calm and boring—read something dull, stretch, sit in dim light. Let your body discharge some of that activation. Then try again when you actually feel tired, not when you think you should be asleep. You're not trying to fix the sleep problem in one night. And now you're starting to see that, which is destabilizing. But it's also the only way through. You can't fix the hopelessness by doing more, being better, or controlling outcomes. You have to let it be there and see what it's actually about. What does that voice think will happen if you stop trying so hard? What's it protecting you from?

It was the system you've been using to stay safe—hypervigilance, perfectionism, constant scanning for danger. And that system just got exposed as unreliable. So now what? You can't go back to trusting it the same way, but you don't have a replacement yet. That in-between place is exhausting. You're doing hard work right now, even if it doesn't feel like it.
